user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of setup_epoll_fd:
```c
static int
setup_epoll_fd (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  int fd;

#ifndef HAVE_MESSAGES
  (void) daemon; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */

#ifdef USE_EPOLL_CREATE1
  fd = epoll_create1 (EPOLL_CLOEXEC);
#else  /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  fd = epoll_create (MAX_EVENTS);
#endif /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == fd)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Call to epoll_create1 failed: %s\n"),
              MHD_socket_last_strerr_ ());
#endif
    return MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
  }
#if ! defined(USE_EPOLL_CREATE1)
  if (! MHD_socket_noninheritable_ (fd))
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to set noninheritable mode on epoll FD.\n"));
#endif
  }
#endif /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  return fd;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function setup_epoll_fd:
void
MHD_DLOG (const struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
          const char *format,
          ...)
{
  va_list va;

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_ERROR_LOG))
    return;
  va_start (va, format);
  daemon->custom_error_log (daemon->custom_error_log_cls,
                            format,
                            va);
  va_end (va);
}
...
#define MHD_socket_last_strerr_ MHD_socket_strerr_(MHD_socket_get_error_())
...
int
MHD_socket_noninheritable_ (MHD_socket sock)
{
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (sock,
                 F_GETFD);
  if (-1 == flags)
    return 0;

  if ( ((flags | FD_CLOEXEC) != flags) &&
       (0 != fcntl (sock,
                    F_SETFD,
                    flags | FD_CLOEXEC)) )
    return 0;
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  if (! SetHandleInformation ((HANDLE) sock,
                              HANDLE_FLAG_INHERIT,
                              0))
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
  return ! 0;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected all provided code fragments: setup_epoll_fd, the MHD_DLOG implementation, the MHD_socket_noninheritable_ implementation, and the related macro MHD_socket_last_strerr_. None of these contain any use of memcmp (or other memory-comparison functions) to compare null-terminated strings. Comparisons present are integer checks (e.g. fd == MHD_INVALID_SOCKET, ((flags | FD_CLOEXEC) != flags)), and logging uses formatted output, not memcmp-based string comparison. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14, so nothing needs to be flagged for investigation.
